title: AB 2514
content:
The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 34171 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to define terms related to administrative budget and administrative cost allowance for successor agencies. The administrative cost allowance for successor agencies is defined as the maximum amount of administrative costs that can be paid from the Redevelopment Property Tax Trust Fund. It is set at 5% of property tax allocated for the period January 1, 2012, through June 30, 2012, and up to 3% for each fiscal year ending on June 30, 2016. The allowance cannot be less than $250,000 unless reduced by the oversight board or by agreement with the successor agency. Starting July 1, 2016, the administrative cost allowance for successor agencies is up to 3% of the property tax distributed by the county auditor-controller in the previous fiscal year. The allowance cannot be less than $250,000 unless reduced by the oversight board or by agreement with the successor agency. Starting July 1, 2016, a successor agency's annual administrative costs cannot exceed 50% of the total Redevelopment Property Tax Trust Fund distributed to pay enforceable obligations in the previous fiscal year. This limit applies regardless of whether the costs are paid within the administrative cost allowance or not, but excludes costs paid from bond proceeds or grant funds. The administrative cost allowance is the sole funding source for legal expenses related to civil actions. Employee costs for project implementation activities are not considered administrative costs. "Designated local authority" refers to a public entity formed under specific sections. An "enforceable obligation" includes certain defined criteria. The "designated local authority" is a public entity formed under specific sections. An "enforceable obligation" includes bonds issued with required debt service and reserve set-asides. Loans borrowed by the redevelopment agency for lawful purposes must be repaid according to mandatory terms. Payments required by the federal government, preexisting state obligations, and obligations imposed by state law, including federal base reuse obligations for the former Norton Air Force Base, pass with a state water contractor. Costs incurred for fulfilling collective bargaining agreements for layoffs or terminations of city employees who worked directly for the former redevelopment agency are enforceable obligations payable from property tax funds. These obligations remain payable if the employee is transferred to the entity assuming the housing functions of the former agency. The successor agency or designated local authority must reimburse the housing entity for any costs related to employee obligations if the employee is transferred to the entity assuming the housing functions of the former redevelopment agency. The oversight board, along with the successor agency, has the authority to appeal judgments or set aside settlements against the former redevelopment agency. Legally binding agreements or contracts can be terminated with approval from the oversight board, with compensation provided if necessary. Titles or headings in documents do not determine enforceable obligations. Contracts or agreements needed for the successor agency's operation, including litigation expenses, settlements, office space, equipment, supplies, and insurance costs, must comply with specified sections. Legal expenses for civil actions contesting the validity of relevant parts are payable from the administrative cost allowance starting January 1, 2016. A sponsoring entity may provide funds to a successor agency for legal expenses related to civil actions challenging the validity of certain parts. If the successor agency wins the case, the funds are repayable, but if not, they are considered a grant. Repayments owed to the Low and Moderate Income Housing Fund of a redevelopment agency must be approved by the oversight board and transferred to the Low and Moderate Income Housing Asset Fund for affordable housing purposes. The curr_chunk discusses the criteria for an "enforceable obligation" under a redevelopment agency, excluding certain agreements but including written agreements related to indebtedness obligations issued before specific dates for securing or repaying those obligations. The curr_chunk outlines the conditions under which agreements with a redevelopment agency may be considered enforceable obligations, including loan agreements within two years of agency creation and agreements related to state highway infrastructure improvements committed to before June 28, 2011. The curr_chunk states that agreements with a former redevelopment agency are enforceable obligations if they require repayment of loans or development obligations from federal agencies. Contracts or agreements between a former redevelopment agency and other public agencies outside of redevelopment project areas that were not properly authorized under Part 1 shall be void, except for housing-related contracts authorized under Part 1. (e) “Indebtedness obligations” refers to bonds, notes, or other debt issued by the redevelopment agency to finance redevelopment projects in compliance with the Community Redevelopment Law. (f) “Oversight board” is defined as an entity established under Section 34179. (g) “Recognized obligation” is an obligation listed in the Recognized Obligation Payment Schedule. (i) "Oversight board" is defined as an entity established under Section 34179.
(ii) "Recognized obligation" refers to obligations listed in the Recognized Obligation Payment Schedule, which outlines minimum payment amounts and due dates for enforceable obligations.
(iii) "School entity" is any entity defined as such in the Revenue and Taxation Code.
(iv) "Successor agency" is the entity that succeeds the former redevelopment agency as described in Section 34173. The "Successor agency" is the entity that follows the former redevelopment agency as described in Section 34173. "Taxing entities" are cities, counties, special districts, and school entities that receive property tax passthrough payments. "Property taxes" include all revenues from unitary, supplemental, and roll corrections. The "Department" refers to the Department of Finance, and the "Sponsoring entity" is the entity that authorized the creation of each redevelopment agency. From July 1, 2014, to July 1, 2018, inclusive, the "housing entity administrative cost allowance" is an amount of up to 1 percent of the property tax allocated to the Redevelopment Obligation Retirement Fund on behalf of the successor agency for each applicable fiscal year, but not less than $150,000 per fiscal year. The housing entity administrative cost allowance is remitted by the successor agency to the local housing authority that assumed the housing functions of the former redevelopment agency. If there are insufficient funds in the Redevelopment Obligations Retirement Fund, the unpaid amount can be carried over to future payment schedules without a five-year limit.
